ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: knowledge about prominent female filmmakers, ethics & politics of contemporary filmmaking
This course provided a breathe of insight into the feminine gaze and how female directors interact with Hollywood and society to put out their works and have an impact on the world.
This was a great course with an amazing professor!  I learned so much about film techniques and also the appreciation of Women Filmmakers' impact on the film industry

An in depth knowledge of a wide array of amazing women filmmakers, and how their work has significantly contributed to different conversations and ideas within the feminist effort.
I also learned a lot about the filmmaking process through regular interviews and Q&As with visiting filmmakers (who were amazing).
I learned how to analyze films with a critical and artistic lenses. I also learned a lot about the history of film and of women in it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It is not often that you get to study Women Filmmakers across all the Film and Media Studies course offerings here, so this was a welcome opportunity! We got to watch and analyze film, read and digest relevant theory, and learn the uncelebrated histories of many women who contributed to the development of modern cinema.
I enjoyed our class discussions and filmmaker presentations. Could be helpful to space out presentations more evenly (had a lot at the end).
I think this course was great, I really enjoyed putting together my personal presentation on a director for the whole class to see.
No weaknesses. Only strengths: Prof, readings, she is an amazing discussion leader.

Professor is excellent, discussions are interesting, film selection is nigh perfect, course structure for homework is good (discussion posts on weekly films, one presentation during the semester, a blog post, and a final essay). The course boosted engagement through really interesting and relevant discussions around the films we watched. Theres a nice emphasis on comparing films across the course which is really appreciated.

Another huge strength is that Professor Chefranova has very interesting, talented, and successful filmmaker friends who came into class to speak to us about their work, life and process. This is invaluable to anyone interested in film or the creative arts, and is what Ill remember most about the course.

The readings were always interesting, with a fairly reasonable length, although the quantity varied a little too much from week to week. On top of the 2-3 required screenings, there was pretty much no time at all to do the optional additional work.

The presentations were another favorite part of the course as students were given free reign to go all in on a filmmaker of their choice, and Chefranova always made it exciting to listen to those at the beginning of class.

The discussion format of the class was great for students who engaged but many people in the class just sat there in silence on their laptops doing nothing. The Professor might consider finding ways to engage students newer to film studies by reviewing some fundamental analytic skills, or just including them more, to encourage those students to participate.

We would have a lot of films and readings each week and never have time to get through all of them. The class was also more lecture-like than seminar. Having more concentrated topics each week and encouraging students to lead discussions could help address this. 
I did love the guest speakers and the content itself.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you love women in film or Oksana, this class would have been an amazing time for you!

Yes! It's one of the most "modern" film classes in the department I would say, where you get to watch a lot of fun films. Or maybe I just prefer films made by women. I would try to take a foundational film analysis class first, but that's just a preference; this class is accessible to anyone.

This course will help you learn that there is a wonderful world of women filmmakers with important things to say that extends far beyond Barbie and the mainstream. Thanks to an amazing professor and syllabus, anyone can get something great out of this course if they put in the reasonable amount of work required to get through.
If you are looking for a great film credit and have some experience with literary/film criticism take this one now. If you havent taken a film class at all yet, I would consider taking close analysis before this one, as some of the students newer to film theory struggled to engage (but some also engaged well!)
Yes, absolutely. Whether you are an amateur film student or have more experience, you can learn a lot from this class.
